video.title: Spring Boot and Angular Tutorial - Build a Reddit Clone (Coding Project)
video.description:
Learn how to use Spring boot and Angular to build a Reddit clone.

We will be using Java 8, Spring Boot, Spring Security, Spring Data JPA, MySQL on the back-end side and on the front end we will be using Angular 9 and Bootstrap 4.

Also, we will be using Token Based Authentication in the form of JSON Web Tokens (JWT).

💻 Code - Backend: https://github.com/SaiUpadhyayula/spring-reddit-clone
💻 Code - Frontend: https://github.com/SaiUpadhyayula/angular-reddit-clone

🔗 Written tutorial: https://programmingtechie.com/2020/05/14/building-a-reddit-clone-with-spring-boot-and-angular/ 

✏️ Course from Sai. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCD20RZV_WHQImisCW2QZwDw

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Intro and Demo
⌨️ (03:50) Project Setup
⌨️ (12:06) User Registration
⌨️ (28:29) User Verification & Async Processing
⌨️ (34:35) User Authentication with JWT
⌨️ (47:48) JWT Validation & Subreddit API
⌨️ (01:00:02) Intro to Mapstruct & Implement Post API
⌨️ (01:16:56) Implement API to Manage Comments
⌨️ (01:30:27) Implement API to Manage Votes
⌨️ (01:41:24) Implement Logout using Refresh Tokens
⌨️ (01:53:59) Getting started with Frontend Application
⌨️ (01:58:28) Document REST API using Swagger & Springfox
⌨️ (02:02:56) Implement User Registration in Angular application
⌨️ (02:14:02) Implement Login in Angular Application
⌨️ (02:21:17) Using Refresh Tokens in Angular Application
⌨️ (02:29:41) Refactoring Home Page Component
⌨️ (02:40:30) Create Subreddits and Posts in Angular Application
⌨️ (02:50:52) Post Comments & Implement User Profile Page
⌨️ (03:04:23) Final part - Implement Voting in Angular App

--

topLevelComment.author: Thomas Andolf
topLevelComment.text:
There are some bad practices in this tutorial, that should never be used in any production application. First just some bad things, there is already full support for JWTs with a customizable JWTFilter already in spring security. Also spring security comes with the JWT Nimbus library, so there is no need to include an extra JWT library. Implementing custom security (as a jwt filter) is ALWAYS a security risk.

Second of all something very bad, storing JWTs in local storage is a security risk. In case of en XSS all tokens can be stolen. And according to OWASP cheat sheet, no session identifiers should be ever stored in localstorage.

topLevelComment.author: Ken
topLevelComment.text: Awesome tutorial! This has been really helpful in my final year project but there's a major security flaw with the refresh token functionality you've implemented. Since usernames are sent with a refresh token in the request and if the token is valid you would log that person using that user name, basically any client that receives a refresh token can then login as any username. The easy fix is to add a username column in the refresh token table. The username is saved on login along with the refresh token so it can only be used for one user only. Either way really helpful tutorial thanks a bunch!

topLevelComment.author: Mindblow
topLevelComment.text:
If you are getting a StackOverflowError on authenticationManger.authenticate() :

*Solution:* write *return super.authenticationManager();*  instead of *return super.authenticationManagerBean();*  at the Bean override inside the *SecurityConfig* file

*Cause of error:* This happens because in the video, he is calling AuthenticationMangerBean inside the overriding AuthenticationManger, but that bean uses AuthenticationManger, starting an infinite loop.

topLevelComment.author: shreyash shah
topLevelComment.text:
There is a one *major security flaw* in the way refresh tokens are implemented in this tutorial.

See, we are storing RefreshToken entity which has id, token, createdDate fields,, which are not enough to associate/couple it tightly with User.
So, in findByToken we will effectively be checking "If token exists" and not "If token exists for SPECIFIC user"

Now suppose in scenario hacker has own reddit account, he can easily use his refresh token (that we provided after after login), then he can generate  new authentication token for any Victim just by changing "username" field in POST \refresh\token request.

Possible solution:
 1) add _ private String username; _ in RefreshToken entity
 2)  in RefreshTokenService's generateToken() make it -> _ generateTokenForUser(String username) _
then refreshToken.setUsername(username)

now pass username to this method from AuthService's login() method

3) in RefreshTokenRepository, in findByToken, make it -> _ Optional<RefreshToken> findByTokenAndUsername(String token, String username) _
ps: you can instead user boolean existsByTokenAndUsername(String token, String username)  too

4) make RefreshTokenService's validateToken(String token) method accept String username parameter: _ validateToken(String token, String username) _
call updated findByTokenAndUsername(String token, String username) method 

you can also make similar changes in deleteMethod ensuring token to be deleted only when username and token are matched
using _ deleteByTokenAndUsername(String token, String username) _

If you get the following error at around 47:44:

"Unable to load class named [io.jsonwebtoken.impl.DefaultJwtBuilder]...."

Upgrade the JWT dependencies in the pom.xml from version 0.10.5 to version 0.11.2.

Be sure to have the following file found here: https://github.com/SaiUpadhyayula/spring-reddit-clone/blob/master/src/main/resources/springblog.jks

under the 'resources' directory.

It worked for me.

topLevelComment.author: Szymon Gryszko
topLevelComment.text: I believe there might be an issue with the logout() function at 3:08:00, what happens if user logs out before 15 minutes and the token was never refreshed? Since the refreshTokenPayload object was not needed before you might call the http.post() passing and object with null values, the server would then respond with 400 and the refreshToken would never be deleted from the database. The UI would log you out, but the API call would not be successful.

replies.author: Mindblow
replies.text:
If you are getting a StackOverflowError on authenticationManger.authenticate() :

*Solution:* write *return super.authenticationManager();*  instead of *return super.authenticationManagerBean();*  at the Bean override inside the *SecurityConfig* file

*Cause of error:* This happens because in the video, he is calling AuthenticationMangerBean inside the overriding AuthenticationManger, but that bean uses AuthenticationManger, starting an infinite loop.

topLevelComment.author: Swapnil Ingle
topLevelComment.text:
Question about log-out using JWT: When the user logs out we delete the refresh-token so that the user will not be able to get a new JWT token. But what about the token that is not yet expired? Do we simply delete it from the browser? If yes, what if someone has active JWT token but the user then logged out and the token is not yet expired? The person with the JWT token would still be able to make calls to the backend.
Am I getting something wrong here?

replies.author: Swapnil Ingle
replies.text: @Programming Techie Oh, okay, got it now. Thanks for the clarification! :D

replies.author: Programming Techie
replies.text:
Hi what you said is correct, this is one of the limitations of using JWT for authorization, to get around this issue we usually try to keep the expiration time of a token pretty short, usually 10-15 minutes. As JWT is stateless you cannot manually expire the token once it is created.

An alternative is to maintain a list of expired tokens in a redis database, once the user logsout, we store the jwt in a redis database with ttl as the expiration time of jwt, and for each request, we check if the jwt we received is inside the DB or not, if yes, then we will not allow access.

I already mentioned this inside the video
